lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can correctly use the verb “to be” in singular and plural, positive and negative sentences.
supportStrategies: (Grammar) Write a sentence scramble: “is / a / She / nurse.” Students unscramble, write and read out. Repeat for “They are firefighters.”
stretchStrategies: Spot the Mistake Detective – Give stronger students incorrect job sentences (e.g., He are a firefighter. or They is teachers.) to correct and explain the error to their group.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can recognise and identify the sounds “ng” and “ck”.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say “kick,” “sing,” “wing,” “sock.” Students repeat and raise one hand for “ng” sound, two hands for “ck.”
stretchStrategies: Spot the Mistake Detective – Give stronger students incorrect job sentences (e.g., He are a firefighter. or They is teachers.) to correct and explain the error to their group.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can complete short sentence frames using the correct form of the verb “to be”.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Write: “He ___ a teacher.” Students complete with “is/isn’t.” Extend to “They ___ students.” for plural practice.
stretchStrategies: Spot the Mistake Detective – Give stronger students incorrect job sentences (e.g., He are a firefighter. or They is teachers.) to correct and explain the error to their group.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
